‚ÄúWhen Walker Percy won the National Book Award, newsmen asked him why there were so many good Southern writers and he said, 'Because we lost the War.' He didn‚Äôt mean by that simply that a lost war makes good subject matter. What he was saying was that we have had our Fall. We have gone into the modern world with an inburnt knowledge of human limitations and with a sense of mystery which could not have developed in our first state of innocence‚Äîas it has not sufficiently developed in the rest of the country.‚Äù

     ‚Äî Flannery O‚ÄôConnor, ‚ÄúThe Regional Writer‚Äù

This is important, might as well repost it here since ZeroMe can't do that like other social media. From Firebox:

How to block a person on ZeroMe

    Find the public key of the person you want to block.
    Find the folder named after that public key in the hub folder.
    Go into that person's folder and look at data.json. Make sure that person is the right person you want to block.
    Delete all his or her files, including content.json. Then immediately make a content.json folder at the same place to prevent that file from showing up again.
    You cannot see that person's posts and comments anymore.

comment.body: @Talnicrom: thanks for the info
@Helloarch: gab is a freedom of expression, no censorship social network. But you have to get an invite to be able to make an account there. You can try asking for an invite @ https://gab.ai/
@Beard: dunno why, it's working on other browsers here though
@Helloarch: What if Gab was inside Zeronet?
anything on Twitch doesn't work on Firefox here
Dunno about you, but I can see on #ZeroMe what I post on #ZeroMePlus . I can't figure out your problem.
I don't know, it's working here. Try using a VPN, maybe it's blocked there in the country where you live.
@Sick Bird: me too, but I can't upload the video in 0, so...
Agreed. The LP was not about libertarianism. Was only about left-winged politics, since Gary started his campaign. He may well be the worst candidate that the LP supported.
@ZAlex: but ZeroMe Plus only blocks people in ZeroMe Plus, not other places in ZeroNet, I presume.
@Helloarch: where do you live? I'm from a socialist leftwing  playground for corrupt politicians called Brazil.
@Talnicrom: the "blocking" idea is exactly about hiding content from users I don't want to see. It's not like make them blocked for everyone else on 0net.
@Durand: there ain't such a thing as "sensible candidate". Weld is a crony corp supporter POS just like any of the others. Another socialist.
@Planteater: not really. Read about Hans-Herman Hoppe and you will understand.
@Darkneuron: except nazists, socialists and anyone else believing in politicians, that is.
@Bashrc: popular != profit
@Brkaka: mas sem a porta aberta para uploads, como vai distribuir o zite pelo Zeronet? √â o mesmo princ√≠pio do torrent.
@Riotpulv: jam
How much? I'm not fluent but I've studied japanese for 2 years, in a school.

@Flyman: I can read kana. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kana and a few kanji https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kanji , 20 or so. Kana is easy, kanji is very hard. I know basic words for colors and animals. You can try using a dictionary like http://jisho.org/ . Japanese people write them with a pen or a pencil :) just kidding, they have a sequence to follow, this is taught in schools and there are books about it, too, every character has a proper sequence of traces, basically. And "aka" ( Ëµ§ or „ÅÇ„Åã ) is "red" as a noum. "akai" ( Ëµ§ or „ÅÇ„Åã„ÅÑ ) is "red" as an adjective. "akari" ( Êòé or „ÅÇ„Åã„Çä ) means "bright". These are different kanji with a similar sound, but very different meanings. And first writing is in kanji (more commonplace) and the second one is in kana (can also be used, specially for kids who still didn't learn those kanji). Kanji is very hard and takes a lot of time to learn enough of them just to read a newspaper, I still can't read them. I use some OCR add-on like "perapera" for Firefox to read them for me and get their kana.

@Flyman: if you want to write japanese characters in a computer, you have to install an IME to do that. I recommend Google IME for that https://www.google.com/ime/ since it's available for more than one OS and is integrated with their search base, so you can try searching for the appropriated kanji, but it's only in japanese, you have to understand some japanese to understand the search. I even double-check the kanji with jisho.org or some other dictionary.
